Yes, there are definitely steps that can be taken to reduce the impact of human activities on fish navigation. One important step is to reduce pollution in the ocean, which can disrupt chemical cues and other navigation signals. This can be accomplished through measures such as reducing plastic waste, regulating the discharge of pollutants into the ocean, and cleaning up oil spills quickly and efficiently.

Reducing greenhouse gas emissions to slow the pace of climate change is also crucial, as this can help to maintain stable ocean temperature and currents, which are important for fish migration.

To avoid disrupting magnetic fields that fish use for navigation, certain engineering and design considerations can be made for infrastructural projects constructed offshore. For instance, wind turbines and oil rigs can be designed to minimize their impact on the surrounding magnetic field.

Overall, reducing our impact on the ocean and its inhabitants will require a combination of policy changes, industrial practices, and individual actions that all contribute towards a healthy ocean environment.
